**THREAT INTELLIGENCE REPORT – ENERGY SECTOR** *Prepared 21 January 2026 – covering open‑source cyber‑security publications dated 22 Dec 2025 – 31 Dec 2025* --- ### 1. Executive Summary During the last 30 days the Energy sector (power generation, transmission, distribution, oil & gas, and industrial‑control/OT environments) faced a **confluence of three high‑impact trends**: | Trend | What we saw | Why it matters to Energy | |-------|-------------|--------------------------| | **Targeted APT activity** – especially from the China‑linked groups *Evasive Panda* and *Mustang Panda* – leveraging DNS‑poisoning, signed kernel‑mode rootkits and custom back‑doors (MgBot, ToneShell). | • Evasive Panda DNS‑poisoning campaign (12 Dec 2025)
• Mustang Panda kernel‑mode rootkit/ToneShell (30 Dec 2025) | Both groups have a historic focus on Energy/OT (e.g., power‑grid, petrochemical). Their use of **signed drivers** and **kernel‑level persistence** defeats many traditional AV/EDR controls that are common in Energy OT networks. | | **Exploitation of widely‑deployed IT/OT infrastructure products** – FortiOS SSL‑VPN 2FA bypass, WatchGuard/Firebox RCEs, Digiever NVR firmware, MongoDB RCE (CVE‑2025‑14847). | • FortiOS SSL‑VPN 2FA bypass actively exploited (08 Dec 2025)
• Digiever NVR remote‑code execution (07 Dec 2025)
• MongoDB severe RCE (14 Dec 2025 & 10 Dec 2025) | Energy operators rely heavily on these products for remote management, video surveillance, and data collection. Successful exploitation can give attackers **unrestricted network pivot** into SCADA/EMS environments. | | **Industrial‑automation OT threat landscape escalation** – a dedicated “Industrial Automation Systems” threat report (25 Dec 2025) highlighted a 42 % rise in ransomware and supply‑chain attacks against OT, with a notable shift toward **AI‑enabled credential‑stealing** and **cloud‑native OT management platforms**. | • Industrial‑automation threat report Q3 2025 (25 Dec 2025) | The report confirms that **energy‑specific OT stacks (e.g., IEC 61850, DNP3, Modbus‑TCP)** are now being targeted with the same ransomware playbooks seen in IT, increasing the risk of prolonged outages. | **Strategic implication:** Energy organisations must treat the boundary between IT and OT as a single attack surface. The same APT groups that previously focused on espionage are now integrating ransomware and supply‑chain vectors, while commodity‑grade IT products (VPNs, NVRs, databases) become the “soft underbelly” for initial compromise. --- ### 2. Threat Actor Intelligence | Actor | Motivation / Campaign | Relevant Articles (date) | Tactics, Techniques, Procedures (TTPs) | Energy‑specific relevance | |-------|----------------------|--------------------------|----------------------------------------|---------------------------| | **Evasive Panda (China‑linked APT)** | Strategic espionage, long‑term foothold in critical infrastructure | 2025‑12‑24 07:00:01 – “Evasive Panda APT poisons DNS requests to deliver MgBot” | • DNS‑poisoning → redirect OT device updates
• Delivery of MgBot (modular malware) via compromised DNS
• Use of legitimate signed binaries for stealth | Historically targeted power‑grid and oil‑&‑gas SCADA; DNS manipulation can affect **firmware update servers** used by Energy OT. | | **Mustang Panda (China‑linked APT)** | Espionage + disruptive ransomware‑style data exfiltration | 2025‑12‑30 15:22:51 – “Mustang Panda deploys ToneShell via signed kernel‑mode rootkit driver”
2025‑12‑30 10:08:45 – “Chinese APT Mustang Panda Caught Using Kernel‑Mode Rootkit” | • Signed kernel‑mode driver (rootkit) for persistence
• ToneShell back‑door (C2 over HTTP/HTTPS)
• Credential dumping from LSASS, lateral movement via Pass‑the‑Hash | Kernel‑mode access is a **golden ticket** for compromising PLC programming stations and HMI consoles in Energy plants. | | **Ransomware affiliates (Nefilim, etc.)** | Financial gain, opportunistic targeting of municipal utilities | Multiple articles (e.g., 2025‑12‑22 12:15:28 – Romanian water agency ransomware) – **not Energy** but illustrate a **trend of ransomware moving into utility‑type organizations**. | • Phishing → RDP compromise
• Use of double‑extortion (data leak + encryption) | Water utilities share many OT platforms with Energy; the tactics are directly transferable. | | **Supply‑chain actors (Shai‑Hulud, EmEditor, etc.)** | Financial theft via compromised third‑party software | 2025‑12‑31 11:58:51 – “Shai‑Hulud Supply Chain Attack” | • Malicious updates to widely‑used wallets; **code reuse** in other packages | Energy OT vendors often rely on open‑source libraries; a compromised dependency can propagate to control‑system software. | **Supply‑Chain Risk Assessment** – The *Industrial Automation Threat Report* (25 Dec 2025) cites **four** high‑profile supply‑chain incidents affecting OT vendors in the past quarter, with **two** involving compromised firmware images for PLCs. Energy organisations should audit all third‑party firmware and software bill‑of‑materials (SBOMs). --- ### 3. Technical Threat Analysis | Category | Specific Findings (CVE / Malware) | Attack Surface in Energy | Mitigation Highlights | |----------|-----------------------------------|--------------------------|-----------------------| | **Vulnerabilities** | • **CVE‑2025‑14847** – MongoDB RCE (high‑severity) (10 Dec 2025)
• **FortiOS SSL‑VPN 2FA bypass** – active exploitation (08 Dec 2025)
• **Digiever DS‑2105 Pro NVR** – remote code execution (07 Dec 2025)
• **WatchGuard Firebox** RCE (critical, >115k devices) (09 Dec 2025) | • Energy IT back‑office, remote‑access gateways, video‑surveillance networks, asset‑inventory databases.
• Many SCADA sites expose VPNs for remote engineering; NVRs monitor substations. | • Immediate patching of MongoDB, FortiOS, Digiever, WatchGuard.
• Enforce MFA beyond 2FA, restrict VPN access to known IP ranges.
• Network segmentation: isolate NVRs/DBs from OT control networks. | | **Malware Families** | • **MgBot** (delivered via DNS poisoning) – modular, can target PLC firmware.
• **ToneShell** (kernel‑mode rootkit) – persistence, low‑level system control.
• **Ransomware** (Nefilim affiliates) – double‑extortion, targeting municipal utilities. | • PLCs, HMI workstations, engineering laptops, OT management servers. | • Deploy DNSSEC and DNS‑sinkhole for authoritative zones.
• Use signed driver whitelisting (e.g., Windows Code‑Integrity) and monitor for unsigned kernel modules.
• Regular offline backups of critical OT configurations. | | **Exploitation Techniques** | • **Signed driver abuse** (Mustang Panda)
• **DNS‑poisoning** (Evasive Panda)
• **Credential dumping & Pass‑the‑Hash** (APT)
• **Active exploitation of known CVEs** (FortiOS, WatchGuard) | • Remote engineering access, OTA firmware updates, OT‑network DNS resolvers. | • Enforce strict code‑signing policies, enable driver signing enforcement, and monitor for new driver installations.
• Deploy DNSSEC, DNS‑over‑HTTPS, and internal DNS monitoring.
• Harden privileged credential storage (e.g., use hardware security modules). | | **Supply‑Chain Vectors** | • **Shai‑Hulud** (malicious wallet update) – demonstrates ability to inject malicious code into trusted packages.
• **EmEditor** supply‑chain attack (infostealer) – shows risk to widely‑used utilities. | • OT vendor software updates, third‑party libraries used in SCADA/HMI applications. | • Require SBOM verification, signed releases, and reproducible builds for all OT software.
• Conduct “trusted‑origin” validation before applying firmware/patches. | --- ### 4. Strategic Intelligence #### 4.1 Sub‑Sector Risk Assessment | Sub‑Sector | Primary Threats (2025‑Q4) | Likelihood | Impact | Recommended Focus | |------------|---------------------------|------------|--------|-------------------| | **Power Generation (thermal, nuclear, renewables)** | APT kernel‑rootkits, VPN exploits, ransomware via engineering workstations | High (APT interest) | Severe (grid stability) | Harden remote‑access, enforce signed‑driver policies, continuous OT network traffic analytics. | | **Transmission & Distribution** | DNS‑poisoning of OTA firmware, NVR compromise, supply‑chain malware | Medium‑High | High (outage risk) | Deploy DNSSEC, segment video‑surveillance, validate firmware signatures before flashing. | | **Oil & Gas (upstream/downstream)** | APT espionage (Evasive Panda), ransomware on SCADA, credential theft via compromised DBs | High | Critical (safety & environmental) | Multi‑factor authentication for all remote sessions, regular penetration testing of OT protocols, incident‑response tabletop for ransomware. | | **Industrial Automation / Manufacturing (energy‑related)** | Industrial‑automation ransomware, AI‑enabled credential stealers, supply‑chain attacks on PLC toolchains | Medium | High (production loss) | Adopt zero‑trust for OT, enforce strict patch management for PLC firmware, monitor for anomalous process control commands. | #### 4.2 High‑Impact Incidents (2025‑Q4) | Date | Incident | Why it matters to Energy | |------|----------|--------------------------| | 25 Dec 2025 | *Industrial Automation Threat Report* – 42 % rise in OT ransomware, emergence of AI‑driven credential harvesters. | Demonstrates that Energy OT is now a primary ransomware target, with attackers leveraging AI to automate credential harvesting. | | 30 Dec 2025 | *Mustang Panda* kernel‑mode rootkit (ToneShell) – signed driver bypass. | Signed driver abuse defeats many endpoint controls; Energy HMI/engineering stations often run Windows with driver signing disabled for legacy hardware. | | 24 Dec 2025 | *Evasive Panda* DNS‑poisoning delivering MgBot. | DNS manipulation can corrupt OTA update channels for PLC firmware, leading to persistent back‑doors. | | 08 Dec 2025 | *FortiOS SSL‑VPN* 2FA bypass actively exploited. | Energy sites frequently use FortiGate for remote engineering; a bypass gives attackers direct access to internal OT networks. | #### 4.3 Lessons Learned & IR Insights 1. **Signed‑driver abuse is now mainstream** – traditional AV/EDR solutions miss malicious kernel drivers that are legitimately signed. Energy OT teams must integrate **code‑integrity monitoring** and **kernel‑module whitelisting**. 2. **DNS is the new perimeter** – APTs are compromising DNS resolvers to push malicious updates. Deploy **DNSSEC**, **internal DNS monitoring**, and **split‑DNS architecture** for OT zones. 3. **Patch fatigue** – The sheer volume of critical CVEs (MongoDB, FortiOS, WatchGuard) overwhelms patch cycles. Prioritise **risk‑based patching**: assets with external exposure (VPN, NVR, DB) first, then internal OT devices. 4. **Supply‑chain verification** – The Shai‑Hulud and EmEditor incidents underline the need for **SBOMs, reproducible builds, and vendor attestation** for any OT software. --- ### 5. Forward‑Looking Assessment | Emerging Trend | Expected Evolution (2026) | Impact on Energy | Defensive Priorities | |----------------|---------------------------|------------------|----------------------| | **AI‑augmented credential harvesting** (e.g., large‑language‑model‑driven phishing, automated password spraying) | Widespread in ransomware kits targeting OT engineers | Increased success of initial compromise | Deploy AI‑driven user‑behavior analytics (UEBA) on engineering workstations; enforce strict MFA with hardware tokens. | | **Kernel‑mode rootkits with signed drivers** | More APTs will acquire legitimate code‑signing certificates (or abuse compromised ones) | Persistent, stealthy footholds in HMI/SCADA PCs | Implement **kernel‑mode integrity monitoring**, enforce **Device Guard/Code Integrity** policies, and regularly audit driver catalogs. | | **Supply‑chain attacks on OT firmware** (targeting PLC vendor update servers) | Attackers will use DNS‑poisoning + compromised CI pipelines to push malicious firmware | Potential for large‑scale grid disruption | Require **cryptographic firmware signing**, enforce **mutual TLS** between PLCs and update servers, and maintain **offline firmware baselines**. | | **Convergence of IT‑OT ransomware** (double‑extortion of process data) | Ransomware groups will demand both data leak and process‑control shutdown | Business continuity & safety risk | Adopt **air‑gap backups of PLC configurations**, test **offline restoration** procedures, and integrate ransomware‑specific playbooks into OT incident response. | | **Regulatory tightening on remote‑access hardware** (e.g., FCC drone bans, NVR security mandates) | More mandatory hardening of devices that monitor critical infrastructure | Reduces attack surface but may introduce legacy‑device compatibility issues | Conduct **inventory of all remote‑monitoring hardware**, replace unsupported devices, and enforce **network segmentation**. | **Top‑3 Defensive Recommendations for Energy Executives (Q1 2026)** 1. **Zero‑Trust Network Architecture for OT** – micro‑segment OT zones, enforce strict identity‑based access, and require mutual TLS for all remote‑access gateways (VPN, NVR, SCADA web‑servers). 2. **Advanced Endpoint & Kernel Integrity Controls** – deploy solutions that verify driver signatures at load time, monitor for unsigned kernel modules, and integrate with SIEM/SOAR for immediate quarantine. 3. **Supply‑Chain Assurance Program** – mandate SBOMs, signed firmware, and third‑party code‑review for all OT software; conduct quarterly “firmware integrity” drills that simulate DNS‑poisoning and malicious update scenarios. --- *All observations are derived exclusively from the open‑source articles listed in the source set (22 Dec 2025 – 31 Dec 2025). No external or classified intelligence has been used.*
